title: A Pipeline For Analysing Grant Applications

sentences.text: Data mining techniques can transform massive amounts of unstructured data into quantitative data that quickly reveal insights, trends, and patterns behind the original data.

In this paper, a data mining model is applied to analyse the 2019 grant applications submitted to an Australian Government research funding agency to investigate whether grant schemes successfully identifies innovative project proposals, as intended.
The grant applications are peer-reviewed research proposals that include specific 'innovation and creativity' (IC) scores assigned by reviewers.
In addition to predicting the IC score for each research proposal, we are particularly interested in understanding the vocabulary of innovative proposals.
In order to solve this problem, various data mining models and feature encoding algorithms are studied and explored.
As a result, we propose a model with the best performance, a Random Forest (RF) classifier over documents encoded with features denoting the presence or absence of unigrams.
In specific, the unigram terms are encoded by a modified Term Frequency - Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF.
Besides the proposed model, this paper also presents a rigorous experimental pipeline for analysing grant applications, and the experimental results prove its feasibility.
In the 21st century, the importance of developing cutting-edge scientific research is self-evident for every country.
Therefore, each country's government research funding agencies are willing to provide much scientific research funding to support essential and cutting-edge scientific research each year.
Determining whether a scientific research project is worthy of funding is a significant and rigorous step for funding agencies.
To obtain financial support, scientists and researchers always write research proposals to present their research plans and explain the significance of the project to the funding agencies.
Usually, the government research funding agencies receive thousands of research proposals each year, which are reviewed only by expert panels.

However, with the increase in the number of research proposals and the development of data mining techniques, funding agencies are increasingly using data mining models to assist in the manual review of research proposals.
At the same time, it must be made clear that relying solely on data mining models to replace manual checks is not reliable.
Applying data mining models to a research proposal has several benefits.

First, data mining models can briefly introduce the essential features of the research proposals to help human evaluators better screen the excellent research proposals, such as the influential features of the data mining models across all the research proposals.
Second, an effective data mining model can help human evaluators understand the research proposals’ strengths and weaknesses during the manual review process.
Next, a high-quality data mining model can be applied to develop procedures and guidelines for human assessors to evaluate future research proposals to improve the quality of assessments.
Fourth, for government or funding agencies, different funding projects should be established to improve the quality of various types of research.
Data mining models can better understand how to ensure that human evaluators respond to these necessary qualities.

Based on the benefits and motivations mentioned above, we hope to apply a data mining model with an appropriate feature extraction technique to predict high IC-score research proposals based on the IC scores assigned by the expert reviewers.

Meanwhile, the other primary goal of the project is to develop a predictive vocabulary for contemporaneous proposals and to understand how the model inferred research proposals with high IC scores from the data features.

In addition, we focus on proposing an efficient feature extraction technique rather than the choice of classifiers, so we choose the very common Decision Tree (DT) and RF classifiers for experimental comparison.
The contributions of this paper are listed as follows:
A strict experimental pipeline for analysing grant applications is given, and the experimental results prove its feasibility.
A model is proposed with a Random Forest classifier over documents encoded with features denoting the presence or absence of unigram terms.
The unigram terms are encoded by a modified Term Frequency - Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF.
The proposed model for predicting high IC-score research proposals can achieve an accuracy of 84.17% across all types of grant applications.
This paper is divided into six sections.
In the first section, the project's motivation and problem statement are briefly introduced.
In section 2, the background and related work of this project are introduced.
The methodology section mainly describes the pipeline we apply for this research project.
Section 4 brings the overall design of the project.
Then, the experimental settings and implementations with the hardware platforms are introduced in this section.
The fifth section gives the experimental results of this project and carries on the further analysis.
Conclusions and future work are described in section 6.
2.1 Computer science in evaluating grant applications.
Oztaysi et al. [2] proposed a multi-criteria approach to evaluate research proposals based on interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy sets.
In this method, a fuzzy preference relation matrix was used to determine the relative importance of criteria.
The Preference Selection Index (PSI) was another interesting method to evaluate research grant applications [3].
One advantage of applying the PSI method was that the researcher did not need to determine the weight criteria.
Another similar and recently related work was the research paper classification system built based on the TF-IDF and LDA schemes [4].
This system used a Latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA) scheme to extract representative keywords from the abstract of each paper [5].
The K-means clustering algorithm [6] was applied to group papers with similar topics based on the TF-IDF vector encoding of each paper.
The results showed that the LDA with 30 keywords using TF-IDF obtained the best F-score compared with the LDA with fewer keywords.
2.2 Term vectors and statistical measures in text representation.
TF-IDF is commonly used in data mining and information retrieval.
TF indicates the frequency of a word in a document or a collection of documents.
When calculating TF, all the words from documents are treated as equally important.
However, in practice, people only pay attention to a certain of words.
For example, “this", “are", and “it" usually do not represent important in most cases.
Then, the IDF is implemented to adjust the term weights in documents which can increase the weights of those rare but important words and weigh down those frequent words but less important.
In 2016, Guo and Yang [7] analysed the shortcomings of the TF-IDF algorithm.
Then, an intra-class dispersion algorithm based on TF-IDF was proposed.
Chen et al. [8] proposed a new term weighting technique called Term Frequency & Inverse Gravity Moment (TF-IGM), which was mainly used to measure the class discrimination of a term.
The experimental results showed that the TF-IGM performed better than the traditional TF-IDF in three standard corpora.
Das and Chakraborty [9] proposed a text sentiment classification technique based on the TF-IDF algorithm and Next Word Negation (NWN).
In addition, this study also compared the binary bag of words, TF-IDF, and TF-IDF with NWN algorithms.
Fan and Qin [10] proposed another improved TF-IDF algorithm, TF-IDCRF, which focused on the relationship between classes in the classification model.
In 2019, an improved TF-IDF algorithm based on classification discrimination strength was proposed for text classification [11].
2.3 Data mining models in text classification.
In the field of data mining, the DT classifier is widely welcome for its advantage of showing how models make decisions according to the data features [12].
RF classifier is another popular data mining model.
The term forest can be interpreted to mean that each classifier in the ensemble is a DT classifier, while all combinations of classifiers are a forest [13].
In the RF classifier, each decision tree also selects the optimal attribute based on the Attribute Selection Measures (ASM).
At the same time, each decision tree depends independently on a random sample.
The RF classifier votes on each tree in specific classification problems and selects the most popular category as the final result.
In 2016, a news classification method was proposed based on the TF-IDF algorithm and Support Vector Machine (SVM) [14].
Based on a different number of n-grams and various data sets, five data mining classifiers were built and compared [15].
The results can guide researchers to select an appropriate data mining model according to the size of the data set.

Four different data mining models were implemented with five different ensemble methods, and the experimental results showed that the RF classifier with the Bagging ensemble method achieved the best performance [16].
Wongso et al. [17] applied TF-IDF and SVD algorithms [18] to the feature selection step and compare the two algorithms.
At the same time, the Multivariate Bernoulli Naive Bayes [19], and SVM were compared in this study.
Finally, with the combination of TF-IDF and Multivariate Bernoulli Naive Bayes, news articles in the Indonesian Language corpus were classified, and the best result was obtained [17].
This section details the workflow of our proposed pipeline and the data mining model.
Fig. 1 shows the pipeline of analysing grant applications.
3.1 Data set.
The data set used to analyse the grant applications is the 2019 grant applications submitted to an Australian Government research funding agency.
3,805 research proposals are given in this data set with peer-reviewed IC scores (1 - 7).
In addition, the entire data set contains different types of grant applications, such as Synergy Grants, Standard Project Grants, and Ideas Grants.
Besides the IC score, reviewers also score several other assessment scores, such as “Feasibility Score” or “Significance Score.”
Since all research proposals are saved in PDF format, extracting the text from PDF files is necessary.
A Metadata Extractor & Loader (MEL) [20] tool is applied to extract text from PDF research proposals and save it in a JSON file with metadata sets and content.
By default, all JSON files are stored in CouchDB database [21] based on the proposal index.
Before designing the whole pipeline, a statistical analysis is required based on the IC scores of research proposals.
At the same time, some fundamental values are also the basis of designing the entire pipeline, such as the median IC score and mode IC score.
Table 1 shows a statistic of IC scores, showing that 3,693 research proposals have valid IC scores.
In addition, 99 research proposals do not contain an IC score, 13 of which have an IC score below 1.0, and these research proposals therefore not be used in this project.
Table 1 also shows the median IC score, 5.0, the most frequent IC score.
3.2 Text pre-processing for grant applications.
HaCohen-Kerner et al. [22] proved that text pre-processing techniques could make the model achieve better performance than without the text pre-processing step.
After all the text is extracted, all characters, whether uppercase or lowercase, are converted to lowercase.
Then, the numbers are also removed because the numbers in the research proposals are not relevant for future analysis.
Thirdly, removing punctuations and tokenizing by whitespace are also adopted, which make the text into small pieces called tokens.
In addition, the deletion of stop words is one of the most crucial text pre-processing techniques.
Fani et al. [23] have shown that deleting stop words can improve the performance of data mining tasks.
Therefore, we create a list of custom stop words according to the IDF formula and delete the IDF value of the term from the text lower than 1.0.
The reason for choosing 1.0 is that after implementation some preliminary experiments, we confirm that the feature words considered as important by DT and RF classifiers will less than 1000 words.
Meanwhile, the words whose IDF value are less than 1.0 only account for 0.2% of the total words, and they are all common words such as “next”, “shift” and “other”.
We believe that these words appear too frequently and have no influence on the experimental results.
Finally, text stemming is the last technique we apply in the text pre-processing step.
Text stemming is a technique for reducing each word to its root format [24].
It helps to reduce the vocabulary and surface syntax to get closer to the meaning of each term, and the Porter Stemming algorithm [25] is implemented in this step.
This section details the workflow of our proposed pipeline and the data mining model.
Fig. 1 shows the pipeline of analysing grant applications.
3.1 Data set.
The data set used to analyse the grant applications is the 2019 grant applications submitted to an Australian Government research funding agency.
3,805 research proposals are given in this data set with peer-reviewed IC scores (1 - 7).
In addition, the entire data set contains different types of grant applications, such as Synergy Grants, Standard Project Grants, and Ideas Grants.
Besides the IC score, reviewers also score several other assessment scores, such as “Feasibility Score” or “Significance Score.”
Since all research proposals are saved in PDF format, extracting the text from PDF files is necessary.
A Metadata Extractor & Loader (MEL) [20] tool is applied to extract text from PDF research proposals and save it in a JSON file with metadata sets and content.
By default, all JSON files are stored in CouchDB database [21] based on the proposal index.
Before designing the whole pipeline, a statistical analysis is required based on the IC scores of research proposals.
At the same time, some fundamental values are also the basis of designing the entire pipeline, such as the median IC score and mode IC score.
Table 1 shows a statistic of IC scores, showing that 3,693 research proposals have valid IC scores.
In addition, 99 research proposals do not contain an IC score, 13 of which have an IC score below 1.0, and these research proposals therefore not be used in this project.
Table 1 also shows the median IC score, 5.0, the most frequent IC score.
3.4 Design and apply the feature extraction technique.
We propose a modified TF-IDF algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF as the feature extraction technique.
In specific, if the term exists at least once in the documents, specify the IDF value for this term directly.
In addition, if a term does not exist in the documents, then the term is assigned a value of 0.
The design of this modified feature extraction algorithm follows the idea that rare terms can define innovativeness.
The experiment also considers the n-grams [26].

Unigram is the most common choice for text classification tasks, but bigram and trigram may better represent scientific terms, where bigram is two consecutive words in a sentence, and trigram is three consecutive words in a sentence.
At the same time, when collecting proposals, we also consider deleting the words that only exist once or twice, because very rare terms tend not to be predictive.
In addition, the bigram mentioned in this paper denotes a combination of the unigrams and bigrams.
The trigram denotes a combination of the unigrams, bigrams, and trigrams.
3.5 Apply data mining models with grant applications.

This paper uses DT and RF classifiers for text classification because we would like to find out the most influential terms and understood how the data mining model predicts high and low IC-score research proposals.
The DT and RF classifiers are convenient to present this valuable information.

Based on the experimental result of the high and low IC-score research proposals selection, all experiments are conducted with the low IC-score research proposals (IC score 0~15%) and the high IC-score research proposals (IC score 85%~100%).

In the comparison study of feature extraction techniques, 400 research proposals for each low and high IC score are randomly selected for model training, and the training data is 85%, and the test data is 15%.

In order to analyse the proposed model in the end, the 100 most influential terms from the collections of research proposals are extracted by the function from scikit-learn library [27], which bring us an intuitive understanding of how much each term contributes to reducing the weighted impurities.
3.6 Analyse moderate IC-score grant applications.
We also conduct several experiments to analyse moderate IC-score research proposals based on the proposed model.
The purpose of this series of experiments is to determine whether there is a relation between proposals with moderate IC scores and that of high and low IC scores.
Since the proposed model is trained based on the low IC-score proposals of 0~15% and high IC-score proposals of 85~100%, the range of research proposals with moderate IC score is 15%~85%.
Based on the median IC score, the selection range of testing moderate IC score by testing several cut-off options, such as 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, and 50.
Table 4 shows a list of experiments used to analyse the research proposals of moderate IC score.

Considering the symmetric distribution of the IC scores, new research proposals with low and high IC scores are selected in each experiment, and performance analysis is conducted based on the proposed training model.

In addition to the experiments in Table 4, another experiment is designed to check the median IC-score research proposals (IC score = 5.0) to predict the proportion of high or low IC-score research proposals rather than calculate the test accuracy.
This section describes all experimental settings for this paper.
Initially, MEL [20] is implemented through a set of Python-based methods to extract metadata for all supported file types.
To extract metadata from the PDF version of a file, the Tesseract-OCR method [28] and pdftotext tool [29] are applied.
In the statistical analysis of grant applications, the Python language and Numpy library [30] are used to calculate the median, mode, and other statistical measurements of IC score.

In the experiments of selecting high, low, and moderate IC-score research proposals and implementing the data mining models, the scikit-learn library [27] is applied to implement the DT and RF classifiers.
The python library gensim [31] is used to implement the TF-IDF algorithm and the newly proposed modified TF-IDF algorithm.
Hyper-parameter tuning is a significant step in applying data mining models, and the Bayesian Optimization tool [32] is applied.
The first step to implement Bayesian Optimization is to define the data mining model, such as the RF classifier and its parameters and corresponding bounds.
In addition, we also need to implement the scoring method and the cross-validation setup.
Secondly, the maximize method is used to run the technique with n_iter and init_points parameters.
The n_iter is defined for the number of steps to run the optimization function.
The more steps, the easier it is to find the best accuracy value.
The init_points is defined for random exploration on the parameter space, which helps to explore the diversity of the space.
Finally, the parameter values for each accuracy are listed, highlighting the best combination of the parameter and the target value.

To find the hyper-parameters of the RF classifier, the range of each parameter is set as follows: max_depth = (5, 60), min_samples_split = (10, 100), max_features = (0.1, 0.999), max_samples_leaf = (10, 50) and n_estimation = (100, 400).
For the DT classifier, the range settings for finding hyper-parameters are as follows: max_depth = (3, 10), min_samples_split = (3, 10), max_features = (0.1, 0.999),and max_samples_leaf = (3, 10).
The max_depth parameter indicates the maximum depth of the tree, and the max_features denotes the number of features to consider when finding the best split [27].

The parameters min_samples_leaf, min_samples_split, and n_estimators are defined as the minimum number of samples needed on a leaf node, the minimum number of samples needed to split an internal node, and the number of trees in the forest, respectively.
All experiments related to RF classifier and DT classifier adopt the same setting of the hyper-parameter range.
Meanwhile, the 10-fold cross-validation method is also applied in finding the hyper-parameters.

To evaluate the performance of the newly proposed modified TF-IDF algorithm and the TF-IDF algorithm with different data mining classifiers, the classification accuracy (Acc), F1 score are selected as the evaluation metrics.
The hardware platform is MacBook Pro with Intel Core i7 2.9 GHz Quard-Core processor.
The memory configuration is 16GB 2133 MHz LPDDR3.
Table 5 shows the performance of the TF-IDF algorithm with DT and RF classifiers.
It can be found that the RF classifier can consistently achieve better performance than the DT classifier under the different settings of the n-grams and deletion of rare terms.
Table 6 shows the performance of the newly proposed modified TF-IDF algorithm with DT and RF classifiers.

Based on the comparison of Table 5 and Table 6, the best performance is achieved with 84.17% accuracy by the RF classifier with the newly proposed modified TF-IDF algorithm except the No.14 model combination in Table 6.
The hyper-parameters are max_depth = 22, max_features = 0.9931, min_samples_leaf = 11, min_samples_split = 67 and n_estimation = 102.
To include all the terms from the corpus, we choose the RF classifier based on unigram and the modified TF-IDF algorithm as the final proposed model.
Another reason why we do not choose the bigram and trigram combinations as the proposed model is the bigram and trigram terms are in fact not regarded as essential features by DT and RF classifiers.
Features extracted from the proposed model shows that only 618 features are considered significant, based on tens of thousands of features in the research proposals.
Based on the comparison of the two tables, it can be found that the proposed modified TF-IDF algorithm is practical and effective despite two or three exceptions exist.
At the same time, the experimental results prove that the core idea of defining the modified TF-IDF algorithm is meaningful and show the rare terms associated with innovativeness.

It should also be noted that the newly proposed modified TF-IDF algorithm can be understood as a simple encoding technique, such as taking the value 0 or the IDF value of the term depending on whether the term exists in the research proposals.

Based on the decision tree plots generated by the best performance model, it can be found that the modified TF-IDF algorithm does not affect the shape of the tree as seen in the tree graph, helping to understand whether the chosen split term is rare or common.

From the result of finding hyper-parameters, it can be found that the best performing model does not use all the features to apply with the data mining algorithms, such as the RF classifier only uses 99.31% features.
In addition, although we consider different n-grams, especially bigram and trigram, with removing scarce words, Table 5 and Table 6 could prove that it might help but not always.
Moreover, based on the same feature extraction algorithm, the classification accuracy of the RF classifier is always better than that of the DT classifier.
Nevertheless, the results of the DT classifier are still crucial because the plot of DT classifier contains all the decisions.
Fig. 2 shows the confusion matrix of the proposed model for the “unseen” test data.
It shows 13 high IC-score research proposals are incorrectly predicted as low IC-score proposals.
In addition, 6 research proposals with low IC scores are guessed wrongly which they are predicted as high IC-score proposals.
The number 59 denotes that the proposed model correctly predicts 59 research proposals with low IC scores and 42 with high IC scores.

In addition to analysing the confusion matrix, we also extract the 100 most influential features from the proposed model, which gives an intuitive understanding of how much each feature contributes to reducing the weighted impurities.
The top 100 features give us a better understanding of what is going on inside the black box.
A measure of the feature importance is valuable for internal model development purposes by showing to what extent features contribute to test data.

Although the classifier is only established for the 2019 grant applications and may not predict the high research proposals for future applications, these unique terms are still valuable and meaningful as a reference for evaluators.
Table 7 brings the performance of checking research proposals of moderate IC scores based on the proposed model.
Based on the test accuracy, it can be concluded that there is a correlation between the moderate IC-score research proposals and high/low IC-score research proposals.
Moreover, it is easy to find that the proposed model can better predict the research proposals close to the original training set settings (0~15% for low IC score and 85%~100% for high IC score).

Based on the confusion matrix above and the experimental results of checking moderate IC-score research proposals, it can be found that the model is always more accurate in predicting research proposals with low IC scores than with high IC scores.
Meanwhile, the research proposals with the median IC score of 5.0 are predicted to be about 37.2% with high-IC score research proposals and about 62.8% with low-IC score research proposals.
Therefore, it can be concluded that research proposals with high IC scores use more diverse language than those with low IC-score.
In addition to the experiments analysing all grant applications, we follow the same pipeline and establish a new model to evaluate Ideas Grant applications only, the one with innovation criteria.
Applying the same method but with different hyper-parameters, the best performing model for analysing the Ideas Grants can reach an accuracy of 82.5%.
In every Ideas Grant application, there is a section called “Innovation and Creativity statement.”
We also extract this part from each Ideas grant and analyse using the proposed pipeline.
The experimental result shows that the proposed method can achieve 68.33% accuracy on analysing “Innovation and Creativity statement” sections only from Ideas Grants.

Although we guess the IC score is more relevant to the “Innovation and Creativity statement” compared with other sections, as evaluators may describe their innovation in this section, the experimental result does not support our guess.
In summary, a pipeline for analysing grant applications has been proposed with several crucial steps.
The proposed data mining model is an RF classifier over documents encoded with features denoting the presence or absence of unigrams.
Specifically, the unigram terms are encoded by a modified Term Frequency - Inverse Document Frequency(TF-IDF) algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF.
As a result, the proposed model achieves an accuracy of 84.17% based on all types of grant applications.
In addition, we also build experiments for Ideas Grants only and “Innovation and Creativity statement” single section.
The future work can be carried out from different perspectives.
Firstly, innovation should not be the only evaluation criterion.

In order to better evaluate the entire grant application, we should consider other evaluation scores and establish a more comprehensive system that can predict a grant application based on multiple criteria.
Secondly, in the future, this project can also apply some other effective data mining models, such as SVM, AdaBoost, and Xgboost.
In addition, the pre-trained language models in the Natural Language Processing (NLP) field perform well in understanding text semantics, which can also be our next research focus.
Thirdly, our proposed method cannot predict future grant applications because the current data set contains only key terms for 2019 and does not represent future grant applications.
Therefore, it is an important research topic to consider building a long-term data mining model to predict future grant applications.

summary:
Data mining techniques can transform massive amounts of unstructured data into quantitative data that quickly reveal insights, trends, and patterns behind the original data. In this paper, a data mining model is applied to analyse the 2019 grant applications submitted to an Australian Government research funding agency to investigate whether grant schemes successfully identifies innovative project proposals, as intended. The grant applications are peer-reviewed research proposals that include specific 'innovation and creativity' (IC) scores assigned by reviewers. In addition to predicting the IC score for each research proposal, we are particularly interested in understanding the vocabulary of innovative proposals. In order to solve this problem, various data mining models and feature encoding algorithms are studied and explored. As a result, we propose a model with the best performance, a Random Forest (RF) classifier over documents encoded with features denoting the presence or absence of unigrams. In specific, the unigram terms are encoded by a modified Term Frequency - Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF. Besides the proposed model, this paper also presents a rigorous experimental pipeline for analysing grant applications, and the experimental results prove its feasibility.

In the 21st century, developing advanced scientific research is crucial for countries, leading government funding agencies to provide substantial financial support. Evaluating research proposals for funding is a rigorous process, often involving expert panels. With the rising number of proposals, agencies are increasingly using data mining models to assist in reviews, although these models cannot fully replace manual checks. Data mining offers benefits such as highlighting key features of proposals, aiding evaluators in assessing strengths and weaknesses, and establishing guidelines for future evaluations. This project aims to apply a data mining model with effective feature extraction to predict high IC-score proposals and develop a predictive vocabulary. The study employs Decision Tree and Random Forest classifiers for comparison. Key contributions include a strict experimental pipeline, a model using a Random Forest classifier with unigram term features encoded by a modified TF-IDF algorithm, achieving 84.17% accuracy. The paper is structured into six sections covering motivation, background, methodology, project design, experimental results, and conclusions.

Oztaysi et al. proposed a multi-criteria evaluation method for research proposals using interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy sets and a fuzzy preference relation matrix. The Preference Selection Index (PSI) method allows evaluation without needing to determine weight criteria. A related system utilized TF-IDF and LDA for research paper classification, achieving the best F-score with 30 keywords. TF-IDF is a common text representation method, but its limitations were noted by Guo and Yang, leading to the development of new techniques like TF-IGM, which outperformed traditional TF-IDF. Various sentiment classification techniques based on TF-IDF were also proposed. In data mining, decision tree (DT) and random forest (RF) classifiers are popular, with RF utilizing multiple DTs for improved decision-making. A news classification method combining TF-IDF and Support Vector Machine (SVM) was introduced, and comparisons of different classifiers indicated that RF with Bagging performed best. Wongso et al. compared TF-IDF and SVD for feature selection, achieving optimal results with Multivariate Bernoulli Naive Bayes.

This section outlines the workflow of our proposed pipeline for analyzing grant applications, specifically using the 2019 submissions to an Australian Government research funding agency, which includes 3,805 proposals with peer-reviewed IC scores (1-7). The dataset encompasses various grant types and includes additional assessment scores. Text extraction from PDF proposals is performed using a Metadata Extractor & Loader (MEL), with data stored in a CouchDB database. A statistical analysis of IC scores is conducted, revealing that 3,693 proposals have valid scores, with a median score of 5.0. Text pre-processing techniques, such as converting text to lowercase, removing numbers and punctuation, deleting stop words, and stemming, are applied to enhance model performance. A modified TF-IDF algorithm is proposed for feature extraction, focusing on rare terms to define innovativeness. Decision Tree (DT) and Random Forest (RF) classifiers are utilized to classify proposals based on their IC scores, with experiments conducted on low (0-15%) and high (85-100%) IC-score proposals. Additionally, moderate IC-score proposals (15-85%) are analyzed to explore their relationship with high and low scores, using various cut-off options for testing.

This section outlines the experimental settings for the paper, detailing the implementation of MEL using Python methods to extract metadata from various file types, including PDFs via Tesseract-OCR and pdftotext. Statistical analysis of grant applications employs Python and Numpy for calculating IC score metrics. Data mining models utilize the scikit-learn library for DT and RF classifiers, while gensim implements the TF-IDF algorithm. Hyper-parameter tuning is conducted using Bayesian Optimization, defining model parameters and bounds, with n_iter for optimization steps and init_points for random exploration. The RF classifier's parameters include max_depth, min_samples_split, max_features, max_samples_leaf, and n_estimators, while DT classifier parameters are similarly defined. Both classifiers use 10-fold cross-validation. Performance evaluation of the modified TF-IDF and TF-IDF algorithms is based on classification accuracy and F1 score, with experiments conducted on a MacBook Pro with Intel Core i7 and 16GB memory.

The performance of the TF-IDF algorithm with Decision Tree (DT) and Random Forest (RF) classifiers is compared, showing that the RF classifier consistently outperforms the DT classifier across various n-gram settings. The modified TF-IDF algorithm achieves the highest accuracy of 84.17% with the RF classifier, using specific hyper-parameters. The model focuses on unigrams and identifies only 618 significant features from a larger set. Despite some exceptions, the modified TF-IDF algorithm proves effective, indicating that rare terms are linked to innovativeness. The confusion matrix reveals misclassifications between high and low IC-score proposals, with the model performing better on low IC scores. Additionally, the model shows a correlation between moderate IC scores and high/low IC scores, predicting low IC scores more accurately. A separate model for Ideas Grant applications achieves 82.5% accuracy, while analyzing the 'Innovation and Creativity statement' sections yields 68.33% accuracy, suggesting that the IC score may not be as relevant to this section as anticipated.

In summary, a pipeline for analysing grant applications has been proposed with several crucial steps. The proposed data mining model is an RF classifier over documents encoded with features denoting the presence or absence of unigrams. Specifically, the unigram terms are encoded by a modified Term Frequency - Inverse Document Frequency(TF-IDF) algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF. As a result, the proposed model achieves an accuracy of 84.17% based on all types of grant applications. In addition, we also build experiments for Ideas Grants only and “Innovation and Creativity statement” single section.

The future work can be carried out from different perspectives. Firstly, innovation should not be the only evaluation criterion. In order to better evaluate the entire grant application, we should consider other evaluation scores and establish a more comprehensive system that can predict a grant application based on multiple criteria. Secondly, in the future, this project can also apply some other effective data mining models, such as SVM, AdaBoost, and Xgboost. In addition, the pre-trained language models in the Natural Language Processing (NLP) field perform well in understanding text semantics, which can also be our next research focus. Thirdly, our proposed method cannot predict future grant applications because the current data set contains only key terms for 2019 and does not represent future grant applications. Therefore, it is an important research topic to consider building a long-term data mining model to predict future grant applications.

Predicate-transform.label: transform
Predicate-transform.description: The predicate 'transform' indicates a process or action in which the subject undergoes a change or conversion that results in a new state or form represented by the object. This transformation often involves altering characteristics, structure, or representation, enabling the subject to produce or yield the object in a different context or format.

Predicate-reveal.label: reveal
Predicate-reveal.description: The predicate 'reveal' indicates a process or action in which the subject uncovers, discloses, or makes visible information, knowledge, or understanding that was previously hidden or not immediately apparent, leading to the object being understood or recognized.

Predicate-is_applied_to.label: is applied to
Predicate-is_applied_to.description: The predicate 'is applied to' indicates a relationship where the subject is utilized or implemented in relation to the object. It signifies that the subject serves a functional purpose or is relevant in the context of the object, often implying a practical or operational use of the subject in addressing, analyzing, or interacting with the object.

Predicate-successfully_identifies.label: successfully identifies
Predicate-successfully_identifies.description: The predicate 'successfully identifies' denotes the action of recognizing or determining the presence of a specific entity or concept by the subject, with a connotation of effectiveness or achievement in this recognition. It implies that the subject has the capability or authority to discern or pinpoint the object, which is typically a particular type of item, idea, or proposal, indicating a successful outcome in the identification process.

Predicate-identifies.label: identifies
Predicate-identifies.description: The predicate 'identifies' denotes the action of recognizing, determining, or establishing the existence of a specific entity or concept within a broader context. It connects the subject, which represents an entity or system capable of recognition, with the object, which is the specific entity or concept being recognized. This relationship implies that the subject has the capacity to discern or pinpoint the object among other possibilities.

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' serves as a linking verb that establishes an identity or equivalence between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject is defined or characterized by the object, suggesting that they belong to the same category or share essential qualities.

Predicate-include.label: include
Predicate-include.description: The predicate 'include' indicates that the subject encompasses or contains the object as a part of its overall composition or structure. It signifies that the object is an integral element or component that is part of the broader category or entity represented by the subject.

Predicate-assign.label: assign
Predicate-assign.description: The predicate 'assign' indicates the action of designating or allocating a specific role, task, or value to a subject in relation to an object. In this context, it implies that the subject is responsible for determining or providing the object, which can represent a score, task, or any measurable attribute.

Predicate-predicts.label: predicts
Predicate-predicts.description: The predicate 'predicts' establishes a relationship where the subject is used to forecast or estimate the value, outcome, or state of the object. It implies a forward-looking assessment based on the characteristics or data associated with the subject, suggesting that the subject has the capacity to provide insights or expectations regarding the object.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a relationship of possession or ownership between the subject and the object. It signifies that the subject possesses, contains, or is associated with the object in some meaningful way, establishing a connection that implies the subject's capability or characteristic related to the object.

Predicate-is_understood_in_relation_to.label: is understood in relation to
Predicate-is_understood_in_relation_to.description: The predicate 'is understood in relation to' establishes a contextual or comparative connection between the subject and the object, indicating that the meaning or significance of the subject can be clarified or interpreted through its association with the object. This relationship suggests that the subject cannot be fully comprehended in isolation but requires the context or framework provided by the object to enhance understanding.

Predicate-are_studied_and_explored.label: are studied and explored
Predicate-are_studied_and_explored.description: The predicate 'are studied and explored' indicates an active engagement with the subject, where the subject is being analyzed, investigated, or examined in relation to the object. This relationship suggests a process of inquiry or research aimed at understanding, evaluating, or discovering insights about the object in question.

Predicate-is_a_type_of.label: is a type of
Predicate-is_a_type_of.description: The predicate 'is a type of' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject belongs to a broader category represented by the object. It signifies that the subject is a specific instance or variation within the classification defined by the object, thereby connecting the two in a way that emphasizes their categorical relationship.

Predicate-are_encoded_with.label: are encoded with
Predicate-are_encoded_with.description: The predicate 'are encoded with' indicates that the subject is represented or expressed through the object, which typically consists of specific attributes, characteristics, or data points. This relationship suggests that the subject contains or incorporates the object as a means of conveying information or meaning, often in a structured or systematic manner.

Predicate-is_proposed_over.label: is proposed over
Predicate-is_proposed_over.description: The predicate 'is proposed over' indicates a relationship where the subject suggests or recommends a particular approach, method, or framework in relation to the object, which typically represents a set of items, concepts, or topics that are being addressed or considered. This implies that the subject is advocating for the object as a suitable context or basis for further discussion, analysis, or action.

Predicate-implements.label: implements
Predicate-implements.description: The predicate 'implements' denotes a relationship where the subject is responsible for executing or putting into effect the concept, method, or component represented by the object. It indicates that the subject incorporates the object as a functional part of its operation or structure, thereby enabling the subject to perform its intended purpose or achieve specific outcomes.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject is introducing, showcasing, or making available the object, which typically represents information, findings, or a concept. This connection implies that the subject is actively communicating or demonstrating the object to an audience, often with the intent of informing, educating, or persuading.

Predicate-prove.label: prove
Predicate-prove.description: The predicate 'prove' indicates a relationship where the subject provides evidence or justification that confirms the truth or validity of the object. It suggests that the subject serves as a basis for establishing the object as a fact or reality.

Predicate-is_important_for.label: is important for
Predicate-is_important_for.description: The predicate 'is important for' establishes a relationship where the subject is recognized as having significant relevance, value, or necessity to the object. It implies that the subject contributes positively to the well-being, development, or functioning of the object, indicating that the object benefits from or relies on the subject in some meaningful way.

Predicate-is_self-evident_for.label: is self-evident for
Predicate-is_self-evident_for.description: The predicate 'is self-evident for' indicates that the subject is universally recognized or accepted as obvious or clear by the object. It implies that there is a shared understanding or consensus among the object regarding the significance or truth of the subject, suggesting that no further explanation or justification is needed to validate the subject's importance or relevance.

Predicate-are_willing_to_provide.label: are willing to provide
Predicate-are_willing_to_provide.description: The predicate 'are willing to provide' indicates a readiness or intention of the subject to supply or make available the object. It conveys a sense of agreement or commitment from the subject to offer the specified resources, services, or support represented by the object, often implying a positive disposition towards fulfilling a need or request.

Predicate-provide.label: provide
Predicate-provide.description: The predicate 'provide' indicates an action where the subject supplies or makes available a resource, service, or support to the object. It establishes a relationship in which the subject is the source or giver, and the object is the recipient or beneficiary of what is being offered.

Predicate-determine_whether.label: determine whether
Predicate-determine_whether.description: The predicate 'determine whether' indicates a process of evaluation or assessment by the subject regarding the validity, feasibility, or appropriateness of the object. It implies that the subject is engaged in a decision-making process that involves analyzing information or criteria related to the object to reach a conclusion or judgment.

Predicate-write.label: write
Predicate-write.description: The predicate 'write' denotes the action of composing text or creating written content, typically involving the expression of ideas, information, or arguments. It connects the subject, which is the entity performing the action, to the object, which is the content being created or documented. In this context, the subject engages in the process of writing to produce a tangible form of communication, such as documents, proposals, or narratives.

Predicate-present.label: present
Predicate-present.description: The predicate 'present' indicates the act of introducing, showcasing, or making something known to an audience or recipient. In the context of the subject and object, it signifies that the subject is actively providing or displaying the object, which is typically a concept, idea, or item, to others for consideration, evaluation, or discussion.

Predicate-explain.label: explain
Predicate-explain.description: The predicate 'explain' serves to establish a relationship where the subject provides clarity, understanding, or detailed information about the object. In this context, the subject is responsible for elucidating the nature, importance, or implications of the object, thereby enhancing the comprehension of the object for the audience.

Predicate-is_explained_to.label: is explained to
Predicate-is_explained_to.description: The predicate 'is explained to' indicates a communicative action where the subject is the topic or concept being clarified or made understandable, and the object represents the audience or recipients who are receiving the explanation. This relationship emphasizes the transfer of knowledge or information from the subject to the object, highlighting the role of the object as the learner or the party seeking understanding.

Predicate-receive.label: receive
Predicate-receive.description: The predicate 'receive' indicates an action where the subject is the entity that accepts or obtains something, which is represented by the object. In this context, the subject is actively taking in or being presented with the object, which can be a tangible or intangible item, such as proposals, information, or resources. The relationship signifies a transfer of possession or acknowledgment from one party to another.

Predicate-are_reviewed_by.label: are reviewed by
Predicate-are_reviewed_by.description: The predicate 'are reviewed by' indicates a process in which the subject undergoes evaluation or assessment by the object, typically involving scrutiny, analysis, or judgment. This relationship suggests that the subject is being examined for quality, validity, or suitability, and the object represents the entity or group responsible for conducting this review.

Predicate-are_using.label: are using
Predicate-are_using.description: The predicate 'are using' indicates an active engagement or application of a particular tool, method, or resource by the subject. It connects the subject to the object by expressing that the subject is currently employing or utilizing the object for a specific purpose or function.

Predicate-assist_in.label: assist in
Predicate-assist_in.description: The predicate 'assist in' indicates a supportive role played by the subject in facilitating or contributing to the process or activity described by the object. It implies that the subject provides help, resources, or expertise to enhance the effectiveness or efficiency of the action or task represented by the object.

Predicate-use.label: use
Predicate-use.description: The predicate 'use' indicates an action or process where the subject actively employs or utilizes the object for a specific purpose or function. It establishes a relationship in which the subject engages with the object to achieve a desired outcome, often implying practical application or implementation.

Predicate-increases_with.label: increases with
Predicate-increases_with.description: The predicate 'increases with' indicates a positive correlation between the subject and the object, suggesting that as the object experiences growth or enhancement, the subject also experiences a corresponding increase. This relationship implies that changes in the object directly influence or contribute to the rise in the subject, highlighting a dependency or association between the two.

Predicate-replace.label: replace
Predicate-replace.description: The predicate 'replace' indicates a relationship where the subject is substituted or exchanged for the object, implying that the object serves as a new or alternative entity that takes the place of the subject in a given context or function.

Predicate-applied_to.label: applied to
Predicate-applied_to.description: The predicate 'applied to' indicates a relationship where the subject is utilized or implemented in the context of the object. It signifies that the subject serves a functional role or purpose in relation to the object, often implying that the subject's capabilities or methodologies are being employed to address, analyze, or enhance the object.

Predicate-introduce.label: introduce
Predicate-introduce.description: The predicate 'introduce' signifies the action of presenting or bringing forth information, concepts, or elements from the subject to the object. It implies a process of making the object known or accessible to an audience or context, often highlighting key aspects or characteristics that are relevant to understanding the object in relation to the subject.

Predicate-help.label: help
Predicate-help.description: The predicate 'help' indicates a supportive or beneficial relationship between the subject and the object, where the subject provides assistance, guidance, or resources that enable the object to achieve a goal, perform a task, or improve their capabilities.

Predicate-influential_features_of.label: influential features of
Predicate-influential_features_of.description: The predicate 'influential features of' establishes a relationship between a subject and an object by indicating that the object consists of key characteristics or attributes that significantly impact or determine the behavior, performance, or outcomes associated with the subject. In this context, the subject is typically a system, model, or process, while the object refers to the specific features that play a crucial role in shaping the subject's effectiveness or functionality.

Predicate-screen.label: screen
Predicate-screen.description: The predicate 'screen' denotes the process of evaluating or filtering a subject to determine its suitability, relevance, or quality in relation to an object. In this context, it implies that the subject performs an assessment or examination of the object to identify those that meet specific criteria or standards.

Predicate-understand.label: understand
Predicate-understand.description: The predicate 'understand' denotes a cognitive process in which the subject comprehends, grasps, or interprets the meaning, significance, or implications of the object. It implies a level of awareness and insight that allows the subject to make sense of the information or concepts represented by the object.

Predicate-applied_to_develop.label: applied to develop
Predicate-applied_to_develop.description: The predicate 'applied to develop' indicates a functional relationship where the subject is utilized or implemented with the purpose of creating, enhancing, or establishing the object. It suggests that the subject serves as a tool, method, or framework that contributes to the formulation or improvement of the object, which can encompass processes, systems, or guidelines.

Predicate-evaluate.label: evaluate
Predicate-evaluate.description: The predicate 'evaluate' signifies the action of assessing or appraising the subject in relation to the object. It implies a process of analysis where the subject is examined to determine its effectiveness, quality, or relevance concerning the object. This connection often involves criteria or standards that guide the evaluation, leading to conclusions or recommendations based on the findings.

Predicate-improve.label: improve
Predicate-improve.description: The predicate 'improve' indicates a positive change or enhancement in the state or condition of the object as a result of the actions or characteristics of the subject. It signifies that the subject has the capacity or intention to make the object better, leading to increased effectiveness, efficiency, or overall quality.

Predicate-can_be_applied_to_develop.label: can be applied to develop
Predicate-can_be_applied_to_develop.description: The predicate 'can be applied to develop' indicates a functional relationship where the subject possesses the capability or utility to be utilized in the creation or formulation of the object. It suggests that the subject serves as a foundational or instrumental element that facilitates the generation, establishment, or enhancement of the object, which typically refers to processes, systems, or frameworks.

Predicate-should_establish.label: should establish
Predicate-should_establish.description: The predicate 'should establish' indicates a recommendation or obligation for the subject to create, initiate, or implement the object. It implies that the subject has a responsibility or a duty to take action towards the establishment of the object, which is typically a program, initiative, or system that is expected to have a positive impact or fulfill a specific need.

Predicate-understand_how_to_ensure_that.label: understand how to ensure that
Predicate-understand_how_to_ensure_that.description: The predicate 'understand how to ensure that' indicates a cognitive process in which the subject comprehends the methods or strategies necessary to guarantee a certain outcome or condition related to the object. It implies a level of knowledge and insight that enables the subject to effectively implement measures or practices that will lead to the desired state or result concerning the object.

Predicate-respond_to.label: respond to
Predicate-respond_to.description: The predicate 'respond to' indicates an action or reaction by the subject towards the object, where the subject acknowledges, reacts, or provides feedback based on the characteristics, needs, or stimuli represented by the object. This relationship implies an interactive dynamic where the subject's response is influenced by the qualities or demands of the object.

Predicate-predicted_based_on.label: predicted based on
Predicate-predicted_based_on.description: The predicate 'predicted based on' indicates a relationship where the subject is an entity or phenomenon whose future state, outcome, or behavior is inferred or estimated using the information or criteria provided by the object. It suggests that the object serves as a basis or reference point for making predictions about the subject.

Predicate-assigned_by.label: assigned by
Predicate-assigned_by.description: The predicate 'assigned by' indicates a relationship where the subject is designated or allocated a particular value, status, or classification by the object. It implies that the object, typically an authority or a group of individuals, has the responsibility or expertise to make this assignment, thereby establishing a connection between the subject and the object based on the act of evaluation or judgment.

Predicate-applies_to.label: applies to
Predicate-applies_to.description: The predicate 'applies to' indicates a relationship where the subject is relevant or suitable for the object, suggesting that the subject can be utilized, implemented, or is pertinent in the context of the object. This connection implies that the subject has a functional or theoretical association with the object, often indicating that the subject can provide insights, solutions, or frameworks that are beneficial or necessary for understanding, developing, or evaluating the object.

Predicate-is_to_develop.label: is to develop
Predicate-is_to_develop.description: The predicate 'is to develop' indicates a purpose or intention associated with the subject, suggesting that the subject aims to create, enhance, or establish the object. It connects the subject's goals or objectives with the specific outcome or result represented by the object, highlighting a forward-looking action or aspiration.

Predicate-inferred.label: inferred
Predicate-inferred.description: The predicate 'inferred' indicates a relationship where the subject derives or deduces information, conclusions, or insights about the object based on available data, evidence, or reasoning. It suggests a process of reasoning where the subject reaches an understanding or belief regarding the object that is not explicitly stated but is logically concluded from the context or prior knowledge.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' indicates a relationship of possession or ownership between the subject and the object. It signifies that the subject possesses, contains, or is characterized by the object, which can represent a quality, attribute, or entity. In this context, 'have' connects the subject to the object by asserting that the subject includes or exhibits the properties or characteristics denoted by the object.

Predicate-has_goal_to_develop.label: has goal to develop
Predicate-has_goal_to_develop.description: The predicate 'has goal to develop' establishes a relationship between a subject and an object, indicating that the subject is oriented towards achieving a specific objective or outcome represented by the object. In this context, the subject is typically an initiative, plan, or entity that is actively pursuing the enhancement or creation of the object, which is often a concept, tool, or capability. This predicate conveys intent and purpose, highlighting the forward-looking aspirations of the subject in relation to the development of the object.

Predicate-focus_on_proposing.label: focus on proposing
Predicate-focus_on_proposing.description: The predicate 'focus on proposing' indicates that the subject is primarily concerned with or dedicated to the act of suggesting or putting forward a specific idea, concept, or method, which is represented by the object. This connection implies that the subject's main objective or activity revolves around the development or introduction of the object, highlighting a proactive approach to innovation or improvement in a particular area.

Predicate-chosen_for.label: chosen for
Predicate-chosen_for.description: The predicate 'chosen for' indicates a selection or preference made regarding the subject in relation to the object. It signifies that the subject has been specifically selected or identified due to its suitability, relevance, or appropriateness for the purpose or context represented by the object. Predicate-are_analyzed_using.label: are analyzed using
Predicate-are_analyzed_using.description: The predicate 'are analyzed using' indicates a process in which the subject is subjected to examination or evaluation through the application of specific methods, tools, or features represented by the object. This relationship implies that the subject undergoes a systematic investigation or assessment that relies on the characteristics or data provided by the object to derive insights, conclusions, or understanding.

Predicate-are_analyzed_to_predict.label: are analyzed to predict
Predicate-are_analyzed_to_predict.description: The predicate 'are analyzed to predict' indicates a process in which the subject undergoes examination or evaluation with the aim of forecasting or inferring characteristics, trends, or outcomes related to the object. This suggests a systematic approach to understanding the subject by focusing on specific elements or features represented by the object.

Predicate-predicts_the_innovation_and_cr.label: predicts the innovation and creativity scores for
Predicate-predicts_the_innovation_and_cr.description: This predicate indicates a relationship where the subject is capable of estimating or forecasting the levels of innovation and creativity associated with the object. The subject, often a model or analytical tool, utilizes data and methodologies to generate scores that reflect the potential for innovative and creative outcomes related to the specified object, which could be projects, applications, or proposals.

Predicate-analyzes_using.label: analyzes using
Predicate-analyzes_using.description: The predicate 'analyzes using' indicates a relationship where the subject employs a specific method, technique, or tool to examine, interpret, or evaluate the object. It signifies that the subject is actively engaging with the object to derive insights, patterns, or conclusions through the application of the specified analytical approach.

Predicate-is_analyzed_by.label: is analyzed by
Predicate-is_analyzed_by.description: The predicate 'is analyzed by' indicates a relationship where the subject undergoes a process of examination or evaluation conducted by the object. It implies that the subject is the focus of scrutiny or assessment, while the object represents the entity or method that performs the analysis.

Predicate-analyzing.label: analyzing
Predicate-analyzing.description: The predicate 'analyzing' denotes the action of examining or studying the subject in detail to understand its components, structure, or underlying principles, often with the aim of drawing conclusions or making informed decisions regarding the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or category that falls under a more general category represented by the object. This relationship implies that the object encompasses a wider scope or range of concepts than the subject, thereby providing a context in which the subject can be understood as a subset of the broader category.
